awd_abstract_narration:
The influences of climate, soil types and topography on the distributions of plant species, communities and vegetation types are topics of long-standing interest in ecology. These topics have taken on renewed urgency in the context of changing environmental conditions and their impacts on conservation priorities. The type of plants and forests found in an area is largely determined by the amount of rainfall the area receives, its average temperature and its associated soils.  As the climate of an area changes, it is expected that the plants that make up a forest will change as it becomes more hospitable for some species and is no longer appropriate for the survival of others. This project uses a well-studied mountain system in coastal Northern California to examine how climate variability, extreme climate events, and changes in rainfall and temperature may influence the current and future structure of forests. The goal of this work is to determine which types of plant communities will undergo a more rapid change in the species that make up its members and which forests may be most resilient to change. This work will contribute to the conservation of forests through its work with a local nature preserve, as well as with resource management and conservation agencies.  This project will train community college students in a forestry program and will facilitate their transfer to four-year Universities.
 

Using well surveyed sites along a coastal mountain system, high resolution climate and vegetation layers, and species modeling approaches across large geographic ranges, this project examines the role that inter-annual climate variability, extreme events, and changing temperature and rainfall patterns have on current and future plant distribution patterns. The use of sites along north and south facing elevation gradients provides an opportunity to examine the relative effect of these changing environmental conditions on forests that vary in rainfall and temperature. This work will test the following three hypotheses to explain species turnover and changing distribution patterns: 1) the local refugia hypothesis which posits that cool/moist locations will buffer communities from changing climatic conditions, 2) the trailing/leading edge hypothesis which predicts that impacts will be greater in cool/moist locations, as these will be occupied by species that are approaching the edges of their climatic tolerances, and 3) the asymmetric propagule availability hypothesis which predicts that dispersal strategies associated with hot/dry and cool/moist areas will facilitate or limit the rate of change found in an area. This work addresses the critical linkages between individual species dynamics and community change in forest communities and will the inform how researchers and land managers understand the dynamic responses of ecosystems to rapid environmental change.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many plant communities occupy rugged landscapes, with a variety of slopes and aspects (i.e. hillsides facing different directions) and a range of conditions from valley bottoms to hilltops. In the temperate zone, slopes facing towards the sun during mid-day (i.e. south-facing, if one is in the Northern Hemisphere) are hotter and drier, and south- vs. north-facing slopes are often occupied by different plant communities (i.e. groups of species). Global change biologists have become increasingly interested in the question of how these different communities may respond to a warming climate.

Intellectual Merit: We addressed this question at three different scales. First, at the Pepperwood Preserve (Sonoma Co., CA) we combined field surveys and remote sensing to map tree species across a rugged landscape. A key outcome was to demonstrate that the species that occupy warmer locations on the landscape - the south-facing slopes - are also species that occur in warmer, and more southern regions within California. While not surprising on its own, this also led to the conclusion, based on models of future climate impacts, that these species will do better under a warmer climate in the future. On the other hand, species occupying cooler slopes are also more sensitive to climate change and are projected to decline in the future. Just after starting our project, this site was burned in a large wildfire, so our subsequent studies shifted to documenting the damage, resilience, and recovery of the different species across these communities.

We had originally proposed to extend these studies to other landscapes across California, but the field work was disrupted by the COVID-19 pandemic. Instead, we analyzed forest dynamics across the Western U.S. using the US Forest Service Forest Inventory and Analysis data set, in a collaboration with USFS researchers. We found that over a ten year period, there is a very slight but detectable shift in the composition of western forests, mostly due to greater mortality of species adapted to cooler conditions. These shifts are also happening slightly faster on north-facing slopes. However, the changes are much slower than the rate of temperature increase, demonstrating that there is a significant lag effect and the forests may become mismatched with emerging climate conditions. These mismatches could make the forests more vulnerable to drought and insect attack in the future.

Finally, we used the same Forest Service data, in this case for the entire country, to conduct an innovative analysis that uses the tree distribution data to infer more precisely how environmental conditions relevant for tree species vary across landscape positions (e.g., south vs. north, valley vs. hillslope). One of our discoveries was that the landscape effects are very different under different conditions (i.e. cool vs warm, and dry vs. wet parts of the country). We found that trees experience hotter, drier conditions on equator-facing, east-facing, windward-facing, and locally-elevated sites on average, and that these effects are strongest in cool-dry regions. We also showed how these results can be used to generate high-resolution maps of the topoclimate conditions experienced by trees, a new form of climate data that could have utility for studies on spatial ecology and climate change.

Broader Impacts: The results of our research will be broadly valuable to conservation biologists and forest managers, considering strategies for environmental management in the face of climate change. The results have been disseminated through our collaborations with conservation NGOs in California, including the California Biodiversity Network which is informing state government’s 30x30 conservation strategy. Results are also incorporated into a public workshop at the Jepson Herbarium (UC Berkeley) that was recorded and is freely available online, and into a lecture contribution to the Bending the Curve project, an open source educational project for university undergraduate education.
